Guilt, guilt, bat eyelashes, bat eyelashes, etc.

And so comes yet another final instalment 
of the series that has soft rebooted more

often than a melting ZX81. Hitman 3. I seem to 
remember Hitman 2 came out during a slow period

in Winter as well. Must be something about this 
time of year when we&#39;re stuck indoors with the

family that makes people want to methodically 
plan brutal executions. So let&#39;s be blunt,

Hitman 3 might be wrapping up the story of the 
last two games but this definitely won&#39;t be the

last of the Hitman series. Obviously it&#39;s going to 
be strung out with DLC for a while like a diabetic

rationing his jelly beans but that aside, what the 
fuck else has IO Interactive got to fall back on?

Freedom Fighters? The fucking Kane &amp; Lynch sequel 
that I for one would welcome like a snow shovel

to the bridge of the nose? &quot;They&#39;re making 
a James Bond game, Yahtz!&quot; Oh, a game about

an unflappable dude in a suit pursuing secret 
objectives in a series of high-class environments,

that&#39;ll be a fucking stretch. It&#39;ll just be like 
Hitman, won&#39;t it, except with forcible undressing

of women as well as men. Hitman&#39;s the only string 
to IO&#39;s bow, but hey, unless you&#39;ve got two

archery targets and three arms you probably don&#39;t 
need more than one string on a bow, anyway.

And it&#39;s a string strong. I mean, it&#39;s a strong 
string. Fucking better be the amount of games IO

spent perfecting the formula, i.e. focussing on 
pouring more and more detail into the massively

complicated open-ended missions packed with 
NPCs and infiltration routes, and letting the

story wither away to a tiny malformed figure 
clinging to the rest of the game&#39;s trouser leg

and mewling in the between mission cutscenes 
- nay - glorified loading screens. I mean,

I could tell you every single plot point in 
Hitman 3 right now and hardly be spoiling

shit because storyline-wise Hitman has spent its 
entire existence running its brush around the same

toilet rim - Agent 47 was engineered by some evil 
dudes who secretly rule the world, he goes rogue

or turns against them in some way when loyalty to 
his friends proves more important and punishes his

creators for treating him like a soulless assassin 
by soullessly assassinating a bunch of them. We&#39;ve

been around this merry-go-round like five times 
by my count and this neo-Hitman trilogy does

nothing new with it. There&#39;s always another secret 
world government to turn against and they&#39;re all

equally bad at screening their party guests.
Much like Hitman 2 Hitman 3 is really just a new

mission pack for the established Hitman formula, 
to the point of using the same interface that&#39;s

formatted like a furniture catalogue and also 
lists all the missions from the last two games.

Which I guess is fair enough because the formula 
is, as I say, pretty down at this point, but the

handful of new missions still doesn&#39;t feel like 
enough new game to call a full instalment. All

the missions from all three games probably only 
adds up to like two Hitman Blood Moneys at most,

and the last mission hardly counts as a mission. 
It&#39;s more of a gimmick level for wrapping up

the plot. Set entirely on a train, which isn&#39;t 
the best environment for multiple path design,

unless you count going to the dining car and 
having to pick from the chicken or the fish.

As for the other new missions, there&#39;s not 
a whole lot that doesn&#39;t feel like treading

familiar ground, the highlight is a mission set 
in a British stately home where 47 can solve an

unrelated teatime murder mystery and it&#39;s like 
an Agatha Christie story that for some reason

ends with Poirot hanging around after the parlour 
scene so he can fling someone off a balcony.

But mostly these so-called Mission Stories are 
frankly the worst parts of the game. I think

that&#39;s the revelation I finally came to after 
speeding through all the missions getting handheld

through a linear sequence of objectives where I 
follow my intended victim around for a while until

the moment they say &quot;All security guards leave 
the room so I can have some alone time with my

new best pal. Would you like to admire my new 
pit full of rotating knives? I thought it would

make a nice centrepiece.&quot; It feels like mum and 
dad doing our homework for us and it makes the

bottom drop out of all the tension and immersion. 
Especially since they very often hinge on Agent

47 disguising himself as someone famous or who 
the victim has already met, rather than a random

background employee, and them somehow not noticing 
that this person they know is suddenly built like

a gravedigger&#39;s shovel leaning on a tombstone and 
keeps responding to direct questions with veiled

references to being an assassin. &quot;Can I tell you 
a secret?&quot; &quot;Oh I guarantee it won&#39;t leave this

room.&quot; &quot;Do you recommend the soup?&quot; &quot;I&#39;d have to 
say it&#39;s... to die for.&quot; &quot;Blimey, my verrucas are

playing up.&quot; &quot;Perhaps you&#39;d like to lie down. 
After I murder you. Completely to death.&quot;

Yeah, it was funny the first couple of times 
but when it&#39;s pretty much the same routine for

every mission story things get a bit silly. And at 
odds with the story&#39;s tone when the cutscenes are

full of slick behind-the-scenes manipulators 
controlling the world through growly phone

conversations in huge twilit offices and then you 
meet them in gameplay and they&#39;re standing over

the shark tank at Seaworld demonstrating their 
new line of tuna-flavoured aftershave. But I

think Hitman finally clicked for me after I made 
the conscious effort to resist my usual instinct,

that is, play through to story end as fast 
as possible and then use the rest of the work

week to practise at throwing chocolate raisins 
into the air and catching them in my mouth. No,

this time I decided I would go back to the 
missions and embrace the sandbox malarkey

by inventing my own assassinations. Switch from 
the strict musical education to improvised jazz,

as it were, and often with equally disastrous 
results, because Hitman gameplay is still a

slave to the cockup cascade. There&#39;s often 
no way of knowing if strangling a dude to

the ground and ripping his trousers off 
is going to be out of view of his mates

until you try and they all spin around and act 
like they caught you shitting on the carpet.

It&#39;s a lot like shitting on the carpet 
because even if you get caught you&#39;ve got

no choice but to finish doing it while 
furiously maintaining eye contact. So,

you&#39;ve still got to hit save more often than the 
crouch button. Also because the enemy are rather

unrealistically good at figuring out where bullets 
are coming from if you decide to go sniping. I

headshot someone from the roof of a henhouse 
ninety miles away and a dude still runs up,

sees right through my fox costume and opens fire. 
But generally I was having a lot more fun seeking

opportunities rather than being handed them by 
the mission stories. Shame you kind of have to

do a mission story on your first attempt, because 
these environments are really dense and sprawly

and with no direction it&#39;s like looking for the 
one unhorrifying toilet cubicle at a BART station.

You have to play a mission a few times and get 
a lay of the land before you can start having

fun with planning custom assassinations, and that 
means immersion takes another fatal hit. I mean,

you don&#39;t get second tries in real life. Lee 
Harvey Oswald couldn&#39;t run up and go &quot;Sorry,

I was going for no alerts, could we scoop 
your brains back up and have another crack?&quot;
